questions.question: What is the exact procedure when a player is in zeitnot and cannot record moves?

metadata.hard_reason: German term 'zeitnot' (0 mentions) vs 'time trouble' (4 mentions) in corpus
metadata.corpus_truth: Art 8.4 p38-39 covers recording in time trouble, term 'zeitnot' not used

questions.question: What is the exact Elo rating requirement to become a FIDE Master?

metadata.hard_reason: Edge case - Title requirements in separate chapter (Ch7), FM=2100 rating on p169
metadata.corpus_truth: FIDE Title Regulations p169: FM rating floor = 2100 (not 2300 as commonly believed)

questions.question: What special rules apply when a visually impaired player competes against a sighted opponent?
questions.source: FIDE Laws of Chess - Appendix D

metadata.hard_reason: Edge case - Appendix D rarely queried, specific regulations for blind/visually impaired
metadata.corpus_truth: Appendix D (p55-56) covers two boards, assistant, notation, time, etc.

questions.question: If a chess clock becomes defective during a game, what should the arbiter do?

metadata.hard_reason: Term 'defective clock' not used - corpus uses 'incorrect setting' (6.10.2) and 'pause/interrupt' (6.11)
metadata.corpus_truth: No explicit 'defective clock' article. Art 6.10.2 (p34) covers incorrect settings, Art 6.11 covers interruption. Arbiter uses best judgement.

questions.question: What are the exact conditions for a valid en passant capture?

metadata.hard_reason: Edge case - specific conditions (same rank, adjacent file, just advanced two squares)
metadata.corpus_truth: Article 3.7.3.1 (p22) - pawn same rank, adjacent file, opponent pawn just advanced 2 squares

questions.question: What information must be recorded on the envelope when a game is adjourned?

metadata.hard_reason: Edge case - adjournment is rare in modern chess, specific envelope requirements
metadata.corpus_truth: Guidelines I.2 (p57-58) - names, position, times, sealed move number, draw offer, date/time/venue

questions.question: What does 'Kurze Rochade' mean when announced by a visually impaired player?
questions.source: FIDE Laws of Chess - Appendix D

metadata.hard_reason: TRICKY: German term 'Kurze Rochade' for blind players - retrieval must link German chess terminology to Appendix D rules
metadata.corpus_truth: Appendix D.2 (p55): 'Kurze Rochade' = German for 'short castling' (kingside O-O). Used when blind player announces moves verbally.

questions.question: According to FIDE Laws, at what exact moment is an illegal move considered 'completed'?

metadata.hard_reason: TRICKY: Technical definition - 'completed' has precise legal meaning (not intuitive). Tests semantic understanding of technical terms.
metadata.corpus_truth: Article 7.5.1 (p36): 'An illegal move is completed once the player has pressed his/her clock.' Clock press = completion trigger.

questions.question: Under what circumstances is pressing the chess clock before making a move permitted?

metadata.hard_reason: TRICKY: Negation trap - question asks 'permitted' but answer is NEVER (forbidden). Tests retrieval with inverted logic.
metadata.corpus_truth: Article 6.2.4 (p30): 'It is forbidden to press the clock before moving.' Answer: NEVER permitted - explicitly prohibited.
